qas.question: In what type of programs would low efficiency antennas not make a difference in effectiveness?
At lesser frequencies what can account for incorrect assumptions about efficiency?
What is the median level for measuring atmospheric noise?

context: According to reciprocity, the efficiency of an antenna used as a <a0_0>receiving<a0_0/> antenna is identical to the efficiency as defined above. The power that an antenna will deliver to a receiver (with a proper impedance match) is reduced by the same amount. In some receiving applications, the very inefficient antennas may have little impact on performance. At low frequencies, for example, atmospheric or <a1_0>man-made noise<a1_0/> can mask antenna inefficiency. For example, CCIR Rep. 258-3 indicates man-made noise in a residential setting at 40 MHz is about 28 dB above the <a2_0>thermal noise floor<a2_0/>. Consequently, an antenna with a 20 dB loss (due to inefficiency) would have little impact on system noise performance. The loss within the antenna will affect the intended signal and the noise/interference identically, leading to no reduction in <a3_0>signal to noise ratio<a3_0/> (SNR).
